question[question_text]: The learning rate is a hyperparameter that controls how much to change the model in response to the estimated error each time the model weights are updated. Select all that applies:
question[correct_comments]:
Your answer is correct.

Techniques:

 

  • Brute force approach:
    • Try all possible feature subsets as input to data mining algorithm
  • Embedded approaches:
    • Feature selection occurs naturally as part of the data mining algorithm
  • Filter approaches:
    • Features are selected before data mining algorithm is run
  • Wrapper approaches:
    • Use the data mining algorithm as a black box to find best subset of attributes

 

The correct answers are:

Brute-force approach
,

Embedded approaches
,

Filter approaches
,

Wrapper approaches
question[answers][0][answer_text]: Learning rate defines how big the steps are gradient descent takes into the direction of the local minimum.
question[answers][1][answer_text]: If we set the learning rate to a very small value, gradient descent will reach the local minimum in a shortest time and converge quickly.
question[answers][2][answer_text]: For gradient descent to reach the local minimum we must set the learning rate to an appropriate value, which is neither too low nor too high.
question[answers][3][answer_text]: If gradient descent is working properly, the cost function should increase after every iteration.
